intro: Mascagnia buchii, commonly known as the yellow bell, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its showy, orange-yellow tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 10 feet, with smooth, grayish bark and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for ornamental landscaping. Its flowers attract pollinators like bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological value in native habitats.
